job_title: Data Integrity Analyst in Louisville, KY
pros: Baptist Health has been a blessing to work for. In my particular job (Data Integrity), hours are very flexible and department supervisors are amazing—always responsive, not micromanaging, always fair, and just lovely people. Fellow employees are a pleasure to work with, and there is a nice level of departmental camaraderie. For the most part, Baptist Health shows great respect and appreciation for their employees by keeping everyone abreast of company developments, regularly soliciting feedback, and giving unexpected gifts of appreciation. The benefits are great, such as a PTO program that builds up your PTO bank fast, good health insurance options, tuition reimbursement, etc.
cons: The executive leadership clearly has some “woke” leanings, evidenced by the occasional offering of online seminars on topics like overcoming unconscious bias or that kind of thing—but these have always been optional, so it’s never been a problem. However, they have now required employees to be vaccinated for COVID-19, even those who work from home, which is quite an intrusion. They have held some Zoom conferences to “answer questions” about this new policy, which for all intents and purposes turned out to be propaganda for the vaccine. To give the appearance of sensitivity to concerns, they have used the language of “continuing the conversation” about the vaccine—but, since the policy has already been set, there is clearly no continuing conversation. This is the first time I have ever felt disrespected by upper management as a Baptist Health employee.

Central Baptist was a desirable place to work when I first started years ago, it was very difficult to get a job here due to the amazing atmosphere and welcoming family feel. job_title: Hospital Unit Secretary in Elizabethtown, KY
pros: Most staff and physicians are nice to work with. There are far more cons than pros.
cons: I feel like the staff is treated as if they don’t matter. If you call in for any reason less than 3 hours prior to your shift, you get two points instead of one. If you call in on a Friday-Saturday, you get a point and also have to work the following weekend as “payback”. If you call in on a holiday for any reason, you get two points and have to work the next holiday. You only get 6 points in a year before getting a warning, so they can add fast. Very frequently, you are pulled to do a job other than your job because of being short staffed. During Covid, even if you have an immediate family member at home that is testing positive, the hospital is still requiring you to come to work because of being short staffed. Emergencies happen and we get sick too, and you would think a hospital would understand that, but they don’t.

Patients were angry over wait times, but we just have to apologize and smile knowing we need more employees but incompetent directors just say NO! another example, how can the scheduling department schedule an average of 400-500 appointments if the is only 9 of them.. Please, I encourage the patients to voice their opinions to management and most importantly the hospital president and maybe something will get done.  Keep in mind, the Temps that get hired have poor training and are handling your PERSONAL HEALTH INFORMATION. who's to say they aren't more likely to make a mistake.

job_title: Certified Pharmacy Technician in Louisville, KY
pros: I appreciated the experience that I gained in 8 years of service, and I enjoyed being able to help other staff in day-to-day functions. When I was able to do my job, it felt like I was making a difference.
cons: The manager and the director are deplorable. They obviously have favorites and have a select few people that they want to see succeed and train in multiple areas or promote. Tact is nonexistent - managers disregard anonymous complaints and openly discuss private matters among other people. Hiring practices are highly questionable - people with no experience will be hired over tenured technicians based solely on who they know or if they're friends with the director. Perpetually short staffed and there is an extremely high rate of turnover since hiring of new management. This makes it impossible to effectively train anyone because everyone is new. Complaints to HR are not acknowledged nor taken seriously. Fear of retaliation is prominent among the staff and most won't complain about serious matters even though they should. Compensation isn't bad but other hospitals in the area pay more.

pros: Most of the staff is outstanding, however, often the working conditions are extremely unsafe, especially on the night-shift where the staff is often inexperienced in some areas. The hospital had a warm, comfortable and inviting atmosphere. The nurses put patient care above all else, in spite of staffing conditions, but burnout rate is high.
cons: The turnover rate in the department I worked(L&D) in was unusual, the work load was heavy and it was a rare to get meal breaks or even bathroom breaks. We worked short-staffed most days and had mandatory 12 hour shifts, which meant 14 hours of work, charting after patient care was given to the next shift. It was not uncommon to have two patients who needed you at the same time and have to do two deliveries (impossible) therefore patient care suffered, as a strange nurse had to step in to help. Often assignments were unbalanced, depending on the nurse in charge that day.

pros: Good benefits, part time employees could get benefits when I started working there. Some good people. 20% employee discount on certain items. Pay was good, almost great. Every other weekend off.
cons: This is an extroverted environment, also very cliquish. If you are an introvert, you automatically don’t fit in with the “clique” and they let you know. Many people who work here are extroverted to the max, pretty much obnoxious and in your face. Not everyone is equipped to deal with that. Just because some people are more introverted doesn’t mean you have to signal them out more, put them on the spotlight more(like seriously don’t do that) and even cast them out. Also work/life balance could be improved upon because you get penalized for sick days. I understand it’s a hospital, but coming in with an illness and spreading it around is not a good idea.

pros: There are some really great people there (outside of management). The nursing staff is great (again, outside of management.) Food in the cafeteria was actually pretty good.
cons: Management was the good ol boys club. (Though the senior executives are all gone now so this might have changed.) HR is a joke! They tell everything and gossip spreads in that place like wildfire. If you go to HR for assistance with an out of control supervisor, they won't do anything. But if an employee had done the same, they would be fired. You get punished if you are one minute late. You can't use your sick time until you have accrued a certain amount. You can't order the supplies you need because your supervisor gets a big fat bonus if they stay below their budget. You have to kiss certain people's butts or else you run the chance of them finding something to fire you over. The non-retaliation policy for reporting something to HR is the biggest joke ever.

review_title: They are hurting but really trying to make everyone happy.
pros: Huge company that would never close. Benefits were great last year but heard they will significantly change this year so we will see. Have had wonderful direct supervisors. Baptist wants to promote within.
cons:
Pay is not comparable to any other large company in Louisville. They truely do care about their employees but it's a hard pill to swallow making $20k less than  norton and uofl employees. 
If you are a "mid-level" provider, you are looked down upon from management and from other providers with their MD. Baptist has stopped hiring NPs because they can't figure out how to make the old MDs happy with NPs coming on board. 
They appear as if they  are growing as they are buying outside entities, but for the last 2 years they have been cutting employees retirement and benefits. Beware....because the facade they project doesn't add up to the actual financial stability of the company.

job_title: Human Resources Specialist in Louisville, KY
pros: Better than average health insurance. Cafeteria on site. Better PTO policy than most places I've worked.
cons: Worked in an administrative position which I won't specify due to small size of department. Financial health of organization resulted in constant turmoil, layoffs, attrition. Dismally sub-par pay for administrative positions. Everyone in department was constantly overworked and someone was having an emotional breakdown nearly daily with unfeeling and uncaring management doing nothing. Old guard leadership resistant to change, prone to petty internal politics. As someone who likes to go to work, do job, and leave the remarkably toxic/hostile social environment within my "professional" department was beyond salvageable and ultimately what caused my exit.

pros: Flexibile, competitive pay for EMS, paramedics are given a lot of ability to operate autonomously with advanced protocols and medications.
cons: EMS division is required to complete annual online trainings that pertain to hospital staff only. An example would be a quick over 'which color light socket to use during an emergency.' Full time staff often required to work terrible schedules, such as every Friday/Saturday/Sunday. There is not enough PTO time, and individuals are not allowed to take unpaid time off.

pros: Baptist Health has a genuine care for its patients, and employees are encouraged to provide focused attention on the patient.  They are very sincere about providing the absolute best possible care for patients. Additionally, management, from the top down, is superb.
cons: The work conditions are wonderful, I just don't feel that I my wages are in line with my qualifications and the work level I produce.  There seems to be no potential to acknowledge a single individual's performance, and increase his wages, based upon the merits of his performance without having to wait for an increase company wide for that particular job title.

job_title: Floor Nurse in New Albany, IN
pros: The salaries are competitive and facilities are (mostly)new.
cons: Arbitrary and capricious supervisors, heavy and often unjustified criticism, petty rule-making, rapid staff turnover resulting in unnecessary medical errors. Management seems incapable of seeing the relationship between a constant turnover of staff,  heavy patient load, and unexplained directives, on the one hand, and a high level of mistakes resulting from staff inexperience and patients assigned to hospital wards before their medical problems have been stabilized. At the same time, upper level administrators are awarded hefty bonuses while basic supplies and equipment--pencils, blood pressure cuffs, and the like--are unavailable.

pros: The company has a great mission and Christian values. And the employees all share the same mission and values. There are other benefits such as discounted fitness membership, good health insurance if used within the company network, etc.
cons: Working in healthcare is always a high stress environment. I work in the Finance sector which has a lot of corporate demands, short deadlines, and unrealistic workloads. I work many more hours than I am compensated for (I am salaried).

pros: Good health benefits and 401k contribution match.  Some departments seem to function well with decent directors & more flexible schedules/ ability to work from home. There seems to be more cohesion among IT, Heatlhcare Ops... basically other directors who may be better to work with/for.
cons: Recently there has been a lot of turnover in the marketing department and a very negative atmosphere in general on the 1st floor (underwriting and marketing). Appears SR management has turned a blind eye to those who been trying to make positive changes, even forcing talented people to walk in order to keep others 'happy'... very unfortunate.

pros: Kind, caring staff; excellent benefits; some emphasis on wellness;some success with unit-based governance; approachable upper management; corporate culture appears more patient focused than some other area hospitals; focus on and encouragement of evidence-based practice.
cons: Vacant positions currently frozen despite chronic short staffing and neglect of poor income-generating programs.  Like most hospitals, the work is often stressful and tends to reward codependent people who chip in extra, maybe to the detriment of their own health and well-being.

pros: Pay here was good for someone without experience just starting out. I learned medical terminology that was interesting and potentially useful. cons: Not every nurse is cut out to be a nurse. Doctors have terrible handwriting and get angry sometimes when you ask them about it.

review_title: Healthcare system that cares about the customer.

pros: Flexible PRN schedule for students; you can work full time during breaks and PRN during the school year. But like most hospitals, you will end up working some holidays.

pros: Upper level management was very supportive and well run. They were invested in your success which aided their success. They value their employees and the company has many accreditations.

review_title: Not the caring institution that it used to be even 5 years ago.

job_title: Unit Secretary in New Albany, IN

pros: Baptist Health/supervisor/doctor, I work for have been awesome about working with me so I can go back to college to finish my degree.  Also, because I work 32-hours weekly, the company reimburses me approximately 80% of my tuition with a grade of C or better at the end of each semester.  I have been very blessed so far to work at one of the smaller sites of the Baptist Health organizations and with the people there.  They have allowed me to grow and learn.  Also, the benefits, such as medical insurance, vision and dental are awesome and affordable!  My husband works at a bank, and prior to me working at Baptist we paid double for our medical insurance.  Then, this year Baptist is offering the MERP plan which we believe will benefit us even more so, the upcoming year.   What saddens me is that my doctor is leaving to go to another company, and if I don't find another job within Baptist, I will be forced to find a job outside of Baptist.  Also, Baptist is changing the PTO program in 2018, which will benefit the employees and was requested by the employees.
cons: Pay could be better, especially for what I do.

pros: Relaxed work environment and many of the people are great to work with. Work-life balance has been easily achieved while working here.

"Power" cliques and good 'ol boy buddy system are a big reason why Baptist IT is a place to stay away from. 
No career path or coaching are present and Gnosticism is rampant despite plausible deniability.

review_title: Great community, great place to work, great benefits

It's a real commitment!
cons: Sometimes it's hard to be patient as the process gets tweaked! Sometimes I really don't want to hear what everyone else has to say...sigh...
